text: The placebo effect works even when patients know they're taking a placebo — open-label placebos still produce measurable improvements.
Your brain deletes unnecessary synapses while you sleep, literally making room for new learning.
The Dunning-Kruger effect shows that incompetent people overestimate their abilities while experts underestimate theirs.
Decision fatigue is real — judges grant parole 70% of the time after a meal break, but nearly 0% right before one.
Phantom limb syndrome can be 'cured' using a simple mirror box that tricks the brain into thinking the limb is still there.
The brain can't multitask — what we call multitasking is actually rapid task-switching, which reduces efficiency by up to 40%.
Loneliness is as damaging to health as smoking 15 cigarettes a day.
The 'doorway effect' causes people to forget why they entered a room because the brain treats doorways as event boundaries.
Déjà vu may be a memory glitch where the brain accidentally stores information in long-term memory before short-term, making new experiences feel familiar.
The smell of chocolate increases theta brain waves, triggering relaxation — which is why chocolate shops smell so inviting.
Split-brain patients whose corpus callosum is severed can develop two separate consciousnesses with different preferences and beliefs.
Power posing for just 2 minutes can increase testosterone by 20% and decrease cortisol by 25%, affecting behavior and decision-making.
The mere exposure effect means people develop preferences for things simply because they're familiar with them.
Your brain continues to develop until age 25, which is why teenagers make riskier decisions — their prefrontal cortex isn't fully formed.
Confabulation is when the brain invents memories to fill gaps — patients can create elaborate false memories with complete conviction.
The 'cocktail party effect' allows you to focus on one conversation in a noisy room, but your brain still monitors other sounds for your name.
Synesthesia causes some people to taste words, see music as colors, or perceive numbers as having personalities.
The Stanford Prison Experiment showed ordinary people become cruel when given authority — though the study itself has been heavily criticized.
Hyperthymesia gives some people total recall of every day of their lives, but it's often more burden than gift.
The Tetris effect causes people to see patterns in everyday life after playing repetitive games, and it's being studied for treating PTSD.
Cognitive dissonance is so uncomfortable that people will change their beliefs rather than admit they made a mistake.
The 'tip of the tongue' phenomenon is called lethologica, and it increases with age.
Babies have more neural connections than adults — the brain 'prunes' unused connections throughout childhood.
The anchoring effect means the first number you hear influences all subsequent judgments, even if it's completely irrelevant.
People with aphantasia cannot visualize images in their mind — they have no 'mind's eye' and think entirely in words and concepts.
The bystander effect causes people to be less likely to help someone in distress when others are present.
Your memory of an event is altered every time you recall it — memories are reconstructed, not played back like videos.
The nocebo effect is the opposite of placebo — believing something will harm you can actually cause negative symptoms.
People with HSAM (highly superior autobiographical memory) remember every day of their lives with perfect clarity but often find it overwhelming.
The Milgram experiment showed 65% of people would administer seemingly lethal shocks to strangers when instructed by an authority figure.
Prosopagnosia (face blindness) prevents people from recognizing faces, even of close family members.
Confirmation bias causes people to seek out information that confirms their existing beliefs while ignoring contradicting evidence.
The brain's reward system responds to anticipation of reward more than the reward itself, which is why wanting feels better than having.
Anosognosia causes people with brain damage to be completely unaware of their disability — they genuinely believe nothing is wrong.
The availability heuristic makes people overestimate the likelihood of dramatic events (plane crashes) while underestimating common risks (car accidents).
Your brain processes rejection the same way it processes physical pain, which is why heartbreak actually 'hurts.'
The Zeigarnik effect means you remember uncompleted tasks better than completed ones — it's why cliffhangers work.
Capgras delusion causes people to believe their loved ones have been replaced by identical imposters.
Sunk cost fallacy makes people continue investing in failing ventures because they've already invested too much to quit.
The brain uses about 20 watts of power but has 86 billion neurons, making it more efficient than any computer.
Pareidolia causes people to see faces in random patterns — it's why you see a man in the moon or Jesus on toast.
The spotlight effect makes people believe they're noticed more than they actually are.
Cotard's delusion makes people believe they're dead, don't exist, or have lost their blood and organs.
The IKEA effect makes people value things they built themselves more, even if the quality is worse.
Flashbulb memories feel vivid and accurate but are just as prone to distortion as ordinary memories.
The endowment effect makes people value things more simply because they own them.
Alien hand syndrome causes one hand to act independently of conscious control, sometimes fighting with the other hand.
Negativity bias means bad experiences affect us more strongly than good ones of equal intensity.
The brain can 'hear' silence — there are neurons that specifically respond to the absence of sound.
Hindsight bias makes people believe they 'knew it all along' after learning an outcome.
